name: Crotona Park
location: Crotona Park East & Charlotte Street (Indian Lake)
address: Crotona Park, Bronx, NY 10460, USA
description: Named after the Greek colony of Croton, known for its Olympic athletes, Crotona Park has served the Bronx community steadily since its purchase by the City in 1888.  Among naturalists, the park is widely known for its variety of tree species (28 in all) and gorgeous 3.3-acre lake, which serves as home to turtles, ducks, and fish.

name: Ferry Point Park
location: North end of park
address: Ferry Point Park, Bronx, NY 10465, USA
description: If you’re looking for spectacular views, take a stroll in this expansive Bronx park. With one and a half miles of prime waterfront, Ferry Point Park offers unparalleled views of the East River and Long Island Sound, the Manhattan skyline, and of the Whitestone and Throgs Neck Bridges. If a great outlook isn’t enough, how about some sports? Ferry Point Park offers visitors playing fields for soccer and football, basketball courts, and will soon offer access to a recently completed, world-class public golf course.

name: Ferry Point Park
location: South end of park
address: Ferry Point Park, Bronx, NY 10465, USA
description: If you’re looking for spectacular views, take a stroll in this expansive Bronx park. With one and a half miles of prime waterfront, Ferry Point Park offers unparalleled views of the East River and Long Island Sound, the Manhattan skyline, and of the Whitestone and Throgs Neck Bridges. If a great outlook isn’t enough, how about some sports? Ferry Point Park offers visitors playing fields for soccer and football, basketball courts, and will soon offer access to a recently completed, world-class public golf course.

name: Pelham Bay Park
location: Orchard Beach Park North Lawn
address: Pelham Bay Park, Bronx County Line and Middletown Rd, New York, NY 10464
description: Pelham Bay Park is the largest park in New York City, with a 13-mile coastline, salt marshes, shady forests and sunny meadows, a 19th century historic house, the Hunter Island Marine Zoology and Geology Sanctuary, bridle trails, golf courses, bike paths and the only public beach in the Bronx – Orchard Beach.

name: Pelham Bay Park
location: Orchard Beach Park South Lawn
address: Pelham Bay Park, Bronx County Line and Middletown Rd, New York, NY 10464
description: Pelham Bay Park is the largest park in New York City, with a 13-mile coastline, salt marshes, shady forests and sunny meadows, a 19th century historic house, the Hunter Island Marine Zoology and Geology Sanctuary, bridle trails, golf courses, bike paths and the only public beach in the Bronx – Orchard Beach.

name: Pelham Bay Park
location: North Picnic Area - Bruckner Boulevard & Wilkinson Avenue
address: Pelham Bay Park, Bronx County Line and Middletown Rd, New York, NY 10464
description: Pelham Bay Park is the largest park in New York City, with a 13-mile coastline, salt marshes, shady forests and sunny meadows, a 19th century historic house, the Hunter Island Marine Zoology and Geology Sanctuary, bridle trails, golf courses, bike paths and the only public beach in the Bronx – Orchard Beach.

name: River Park
location: 180th Street fence line
address: River Park, Boston Road, Bronx, NY 10460, USA
description: Tree-shaded, riverside park with a grassy picnic area & a fenced playground with views of the falls.

name: River Park
location: Along Boston Road entrance side
address: River Park, Boston Road, Bronx, NY 10460, USA
description: Tree-shaded, riverside park with a grassy picnic area & a fenced playground with views of the falls.

name: St. Mary's Park
location: 146th Street & St. Ann's Avenue
address: Saint Mary's Park, 450 Saint Ann's Avenue, Bronx, NY 10455, USA
description: As the largest park in the south Bronx, St. Mary's Park gets plenty of love from those living in the area. And who could blame them? This park offers an oasis of fun and relaxation in a busy area. The lawns are particularly popular with picnickers, and families bring baskets full of food to grill on warm summer days. Runners circle the park's well-tended track, and those looking to 'get their sport on' spend time slamming handballs on the handball court, hitting and pitching in the baseball diamond, and shooting hoops on the basketball court.

name: Van Cortlandt Park
location: Allen Shandler Recreation Area: Jerome Avenue, South of 233rd Street
address: Van Cortlandt Park, Bronx, NY 10462, USA
description: Van Cortlandt Park — more than a thousand acres atop the ridges and valleys of the northwest Bronx — is New York City's third largest park. Playing fields and playgrounds are scattered about the park's edges, surrounding a richly forested heartland fed by Tibbets Brook.

name: Van Cortlandt Park
location: In front of the pool, Broadway and 242 Street
description:
Van Cortlandt Park — more than a thousand acres atop the ridges and valleys of the northwest Bronx — is New York City's third largest park. Playing fields and playgrounds are scattered about the park's edges, surrounding a richly forested heartland fed by Tibbets Brook. The park is home to the country's first public golf course, the oldest house in the Bronx, and the borough's largest freshwater lake.

From the quiet green shade of its oak forests to the crisp white mantle of cricket players atop the Parade Ground, the park boasts a past rich in culture, well-versed in history, and blessed with the intrinsic beauty of nature.

name: Coffey Park
location: At Verona and Richards streets
address: Coffey Park, 85 Richards Street, Brooklyn, NY 11231, USA
description: Coffey Park, like nearby Coffey Street, is named for Michael J. Coffey (1839-1907), the former state senator, alderman, and district leader representing Red Hook. Coffey was born in 1839 in County Cork, Ireland, and then immigrated to the United States with his parents at the age of five. He went to school in Red Hook and soon began working in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. When the Civil War began, Coffey joined the United States Navy. He served on the gunboat Monticello, and quickly earned the respect of his commanding officer. At the conclusion of the war, Coffey returned to Red Hook and became the Democratic district leader for Red Hook Point. The Red Hook district was locally known as “Coffeyville” by the end of his 39-year tenure as district leader.

name: Coffey Park
location: At Verona and Dwight streets
address: Coffey Park, 85 Richards Street, Brooklyn, NY 11231, USA
description: Coffey Park, like nearby Coffey Street, is named for Michael J. Coffey (1839-1907), the former state senator, alderman, and district leader representing Red Hook. Coffey was born in 1839 in County Cork, Ireland, and then immigrated to the United States with his parents at the age of five. He went to school in Red Hook and soon began working in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. When the Civil War began, Coffey joined the United States Navy. He served on the gunboat Monticello, and quickly earned the respect of his commanding officer. At the conclusion of the war, Coffey returned to Red Hook and became the Democratic district leader for Red Hook Point. The Red Hook district was locally known as “Coffeyville” by the end of his 39-year tenure as district leader.

name: Fort Greene Park
location: Along Myrtle Avenue between North Portland Avenue and St. Edwards Street
address: Fort Greene Park, Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11201, USA
description: Fort Greene's history is rife with important names--Walt Whitman, Nathaniel Greene, Frederick Law Olmsted, Calvert Vaux, William Howard Taft, and McKim, Mead and White, to name a few--hinting at the important role the park has played in the city's history. Originally the site of forts built for the Revolutionary War and the War of 1812, the community surrounding the land started using it as public space shortly after the threat of the War of 1812 passed. By 1847, it was designated a park (Brooklyn's first), and twenty years later, famed landscape architects Olmsted and Vaux began designing its new layout. In 1897, the park, formerly known as Washington Park, received its name.

name: Kaiser Park
location: At West 33rd Street
address: Kaiser Park, Neptune Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11224, USA
description: Kaiser Park, with its northwestern corner nestled on Coney Island, is the perfect combination of beach fun, beauty and functionality. Want the perks of a beach? Head to the pier, toss a line, and see what fish are biting today. Or, if it's just the beauty you want, stare at the sun setting behind the distant Verrazano-Narrows Bridge or go to the Gravesend Bay side of the park for a glimpse of magnificent migrating birds. After all that relaxing, lace up your sneakers and jog a lap around the state-of-the-art track reopened in 2006. If team sports are more your style, meet some friends at the soccer, football, or baseball fields, all of which have also been recently renovated. Finally, end your day with a barbeque at one of the 20 grills within the park. While digesting your meal, plan your next trip to the park.

name: Manhattan Beach
location: Northeast of Promenade, median adjacent to parking lot (no amplified sound permitted)
address: Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, NY, USA
description: This beach on Brooklyn's southern tip is a popular summertime destination for people from all over New York City. As the weather heats up, families pack picnic baskets and come out to barbeque, loll on the sand, and swim in the waves. Bookended by playgrounds, and with two large baseball diamonds on its eastern border, as well as tennis, volleyball, basketball, and handball, this park has plenty of room for all types of active outdoor fun.

name: Manhattan Beach
location: Oriental Boulevard & Hastings Street (no amplified sound permitted)
address: Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, NY, USA
description: This beach on Brooklyn's southern tip is a popular summertime destination for people from all over New York City. As the weather heats up, families pack picnic baskets and come out to barbeque, loll on the sand, and swim in the waves. Bookended by playgrounds, and with two large baseball diamonds on its eastern border, as well as tennis, volleyball, basketball, and handball, this park has plenty of room for all types of active outdoor fun.

name: Prospect Park
location: Both sides of Bandshell
address: Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY 11225, USA
description: Designed and constructed over a thirty-year period (1865-1895) by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the masterminds behind Central Park, Prospect Park has blossomed into a premiere destination for Brooklyn visitors and residents alike.

name: Prospect Park
location: North area of Long Meadow
address: Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY 11225, USA
description: Designed and constructed over a thirty-year period (1865-1895) by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the masterminds behind Central Park, Prospect Park has blossomed into a premiere destination for Brooklyn visitors and residents alike.

name: Prospect Park
location: Area near Prospect Park South West and 10th Avenue
address: Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY 11225, USA
description: Designed and constructed over a thirty-year period (1865-1895) by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the masterminds behind Central Park, Prospect Park has blossomed into a premiere destination for Brooklyn visitors and residents alike.

name: Prospect Park
location: Area near Vanderbuilt Street and Prospect Park South West
address: Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY 11225, USA
description: Designed and constructed over a thirty-year period (1865-1895) by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the masterminds behind Central Park, Prospect Park has blossomed into a premiere destination for Brooklyn visitors and residents alike.

name: Prospect Park
location: Area north of Picnic House
address: Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY 11225, USA
description: Designed and constructed over a thirty-year period (1865-1895) by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the masterminds behind Central Park, Prospect Park has blossomed into a premiere destination for Brooklyn visitors and residents alike.

name: Prospect Park
location: Grecian Shelter area
address: Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY 11225, USA
description: Designed and constructed over a thirty-year period (1865-1895) by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the masterminds behind Central Park, Prospect Park has blossomed into a premiere destination for Brooklyn visitors and residents alike.

name: Prospect Park
location: Area south of Wollman Rink
address: Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY 11225, USA
description: Designed and constructed over a thirty-year period (1865-1895) by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the masterminds behind Central Park, Prospect Park has blossomed into a premiere destination for Brooklyn visitors and residents alike.

name: East River Park*
location:
Along FDR Drive at East 10th Street
*Special events permit required
address: East River Park, East River Promenade, New York, NY 10019, USA
description: How many New Yorkers can brag about owning 57 acres of waterside property? Parks can. Rather than settle for a strip of land offering impressive views of the Manhattan and Brooklyn bridges, Parks filled the area with vibrant activity--building an amphitheater, bike paths, playgrounds, sports fields and courts, gardens, children's water play areas, and walking paths

name: Fort Washington Park
location: North of West 158th Street on the Hudson River
address: Fort Washington Park, Hudson River, New York, NY 10033, USA
description: Known to history buffs as the namesake of a Revolutionary War structure built for the rebels and seized by the British; known to children as the site of Manhattan's only lighthouse, the Little Red Lighthouse, the protagonist in a popular children's book; known to aesthetes as an ideal lookout spot onto the Hudson River and the Palisades, Fort Washington Park is a valued part of the Washington Heights community.

name: Highbridge Park
location: West 177th Street and Amsterdam Avenue
address: Highbridge Park, Edgecombe Avenue, New York, NY 10039, USA
description: Named after the High Bridge, the city's oldest standing bridge, Highbridge Park was assembled piecemeal between 1867 and the 1960s, with the bulk being acquired through condemnation from 1895 to 1901. Although widely known for its important landmarks, the Highbridge tower and formerly mentioned bridge, the park offers natural beauty and recreational fun that serve as reason enough to visit.

name: Inwood Hill Park-Dyckman Fields
location: Dyckman Street & Hudson River
address: Inwood, New York, NY, USA
description: There's old New York, and then there's old New York. Inwood Hill Park is a living piece of old New York. Evidence of its prehistoric roots exists as dramatic caves, valleys, and ridges left as the result of shifting glaciers.

name: Morningside Park
location: Morningside Avenue & West 121st Street
address: Morningside Park, New York, NY 10026, USA
description: A narrow strip that stretches 13 blocks through the neighborhoods of Harlem and Morningside Heights, Morningside Park blends dramatic landscaping with the pleasures of a community park. Built on a steep incline, multiple playgrounds nestle at the bottom of its cliff-like hillside, and visitors pause along its heights to take in a unique view. Winding paths bordered with flowers and trees lead to a cascading waterfall, across from which local teams play on its baseball fields. Parents bring their children to play in its playgrounds and learn in its after-school program, and on Saturdays local farmers sell their goods in an outdoor market.

name: Randall's Island
location: At the far end of Sunken Meadow ballfields
address: Wards Island, New York, NY, USA
description: One of the city’s main recreation hubs, the Park has undergone a remarkable transformation in recent years, in large part through the vision and support of Mayor Michael Bloomberg, in keeping with his historic citywide commitment to the preservation of open spaces and waterfront restoration and development.

name: Riverside Park
location: West 145th Street on the Hudson River
address: Riverside Park, New York, NY, USA
description: Stretching four miles from 72nd to 158th streets along the Hudson River, Riverside Park is regarded by many as Manhattan's most spectacular waterfront park. Since 1875, the landscapes of Frederick Law Olmsted have offered escape from the city and opportunities for people of all incomes to relax, play, and socialize in tranquil settings.

name: St. Nicholas Park
location: St. Nicholas Terrace at West 128th Street
address: St. Nicholas Park, Saint Nicholas Terrace, New York, NY 10027, USA
description: This spacious park is named for St. Nicholas of Myra. It is located at the intersection of St. Nicholas Avenue, 127th Street, St. Nicholas Terrace and 141st Street, bordering the Manhattan neighborhoods of Hamilton Heights, Manhattanville, and Harlem.

name: St. Nicholas Park
location: St. Nicholas Avenue between West 133rd and 135th streets
address: St. Nicholas Park, Saint Nicholas Terrace, New York, NY 10027, USA
description: This spacious park is named for St. Nicholas of Myra. It is located at the intersection of St. Nicholas Avenue, 127th Street, St. Nicholas Terrace and 141st Street, bordering the Manhattan neighborhoods of Hamilton Heights, Manhattanville, and Harlem.

name: Thomas Jefferson Park
location: First Avenue between East 111th and 114th streets
address: Thomas Jefferson Park, 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10029, USA
description: Although only a few blocks long, this friendly neighborhood park is packed to the brim with things to do.  On busy days, runners circle the track while groups of friends shoot hoops, hit balls, and take advantage of the baseball and handball courts. The small recreation center on its grounds offers a fitness room, exercise equipment, and classes for those looking for a good workout.

name: Wards Island
location: East River & Hell Gate (near the children's playground)
address: Wards Island, New York, NY, USA
description: Wards Island Park is located on Wards Island, a 255-acre landmass lying in the northern end of the East River, between Manhattan and Queens.

name: Alley Pond Park
location: Winchester Boulevard & Grand Central Parkway
address: Alley Pond Park, Little Neck Bay, Queens, NY 11364
description: Alley Pond Park offers glimpses into New York’s geologic past, its colonial history, and its current conservation efforts.

name: Alley Pond Park
location: Alley Athletic Field: Union Turnpike & Winchester Boulevard
description: Alley Pond Park offers glimpses into New York’s geologic past, its colonial history, and its current conservation efforts. Because of its glacier-formed moraine, the park has numerous unique natural features, like its freshwater and saltwater wetlands, tidal flats, meadows, and forests, which create a diverse ecosystem and support abundant bird life. The park is also home to New York City's first public high ropes adventure course (the largest in the Northeast), part of the Urban Park Rangers' larger Alley Pond Park Adventure program.

name: Alley Pond Park
location: Alley Springfield: Springfield Boulevard and 76 Avenue
description: Alley Pond Park offers glimpses into New York’s geologic past, its colonial history, and its current conservation efforts.

name: Bayswater Park
location: Beach Channel Drive and B32 Street
address: Bayswater Park, Bay 32nd Street, Far Rockaway, NY 11691, USA
description: This park is named, in part, for Jules Michaelis (1893-1968), a long-time caterer and civic leader in the Rockaways. For 16 years he served as president of the Wavecrest Civic Association, and was also a member of the Rockaway Chamber of Commerce and the Borough President’s Committee on Aviation. He was also a leader in the efforts to develop Bayswater Park. The community felt a need for more recreation space and better facilities, and Michaelis was particularly interested in creating a quality baseball diamond so that students from Far Rockaway High School would have a place to play.

name: Brookville Park
location: Brookville Boulevard & South Conduit Avenue
address: Brookville Park, Rosedale, NY 11422, USA
description: Park with basketball, tennis, bocce & baseball areas, a playground, picnic tables & hike/bike paths.

name: Corona Park
location: Jewel Avenue and Van Wyck Expressway
address: Flushing Meadows Corona Park, Queens, NY, USA
description: The site of two twentieth century World's Fairs attended by millions of people, Flushing Meadows Corona Park continues to draw and delight visitors. As the largest park in Queens, it offers plenty of space for whatever your recreational desires may be--baseball, soccer, tennis, cricket, et cetera.

name: Cunningham Park
location: Union Turnpike and Francis Lewis Boulevard
address: Cunningham Park, Grand Central Parkway, Oakland Gardens, NY 11364, USA
description: Culture, sports, nature... and fun! All of these things abound in Cunningham Park, one of the largest parks in Queens.  Assembled between 1928 and 1944 and named Cunningham Park in 1934, the space has developed into headquarters for countless athletic leagues, animals, playmates, and barbecue enthusiasts.

name: Flushing Meadows Corona Park
location: Off Lake West and off Lake East
address: Flushing Meadows Corona Park, Queens, NY, USA
description: The site of two twentieth century World's Fairs attended by millions of people, Flushing Meadows Corona Park continues to draw and delight visitors. As the largest park in Queens, it offers plenty of space for whatever your recreational desires may be--baseball, soccer, tennis, cricket, et cetera.

name: Forest Park
location: Woodhaven Boulevard and Forest Park Drive
address: Forest Park, Queens, NY, USA
description: A mix of natural treasures and man-made prizes, Forest Park is 500+ acres of options for visitors. With a 'knob and kettle' terrain (a series of small hills) and 165 acres of trees, the park is an agrarian delight.

name: Highland Park
location: Upper Highland: Highland Blvd. and Vermont Place
address: Highland Park, NY 14094, USA
description: Conveniently located on a high plateau that straddles Queens and Brooklyn, Highland Park offers stunning views of Ridgewood Reservoir, the Rockaways, the Atlantic Ocean, and nearby cemeteries.

name: O'Donohue Park
location: Seagirt Blvd. between Beach 15 and Beach 17 Streets
address: O'Donohue Park, Far Rockaway, NY 11691, USA
description: From surfers to swimmers to the Ramones, everyone wants to 'hitch a ride to Rockaway Beach.' Rockaway Beach is a year-round resource for residents all along the Rockaway peninsula, and it comes alive each summer from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day weekend with millions of visitors.

name: Springfield Playground
location: 147th Avenue and Springfield Boulevard
address: Springfield Boulevard & 147th Avenue, Springfield Gardens, NY 11413, USA
description: This park shares its name with the much larger Springfield Park to its south, a site named after the surrounding neighborhood of Springfield Gardens. An enticing settlement area because of its richness in natural resources, Springfield Gardens remained largely agricultural until the Long Island Rail Road extended to this community, stimulating rapid residential development.

name: Clove Lakes Park
location: Clove Road & Victory Boulevard
address: Clove Lakes Park, 1150 Clove Road, Staten Island, NY 10301, USA
description: A protected Forever Wild site because of its valuable ecological assets, Clove Lakes Park has a rich natural history and a few remnants of the past that remain and continue to thrill visitors. Chief among them are the park's lakes and ponds, outcroppings of serpentine rocks, and Staten Island's largest living things, a three hundred year-old tulip tree.

name: Willowbrook Park
location: Eaton Place Entrance
address: Willowbrook Park, 1 Eaton place, Staten Island, NY 10314, USA
description: This unique patch of greenery in Staten Island is many things to many people.

name: Wolfe's Pond Park
location: Cornelia Avenue and Luten Avenue
address: Wolfes Pond Park, 420 Cornelia Avenue, Staten Island, NY 10312, USA
description: As one of Staten Island's largest parks, Wolfe's Pond Park wears many different hats.  To some, it is a beautiful beach.  To others, it is a wildlife and plant preserve.  To still others, it is a recreation area with space to run, jump, and climb.  Choose Wolfe's Pond Park, and choose your own adventure!

name: Midland Beach
location: Midland Avenue and Lincoln Avenue
address: Midland Beach, Staten Island, NY, USA
description: Midland Beach is part of one of New York City’s four beachfront areas. Its orange-colored sands, and the waves of the Atlantic Ocean have long served as a refuge from the congestion and confinement of the city.

name: Baisley Pond Park
location: Sutphin Boulevard & 125th Avenue
address: Baisley Pond Park, N Conduit Ave & Baisley Blvd S, JAMAICA, NY 11434
description: No matter what you expect from your park, whether it's a place to play tennis, handball, basketball, and cricket; space to run, bike, and rollerblade; playgrounds for your child's enjoyment; peaceful, shady alcoves for picnicking; or an urban natural habitat for your personal study of plant and animal life, there's a good chance you can find your niche at Baisley Park.

name: Queensbridge Park
location: 21 Street, Bridge Plaza, Vernon Boulevard, & East River
address: Queensbridge Park, 21st Street, Long Island City, NY 11101, USA
description: This park is named for the nearby Queensboro Bridge, which is also known as the Queensbridge or 59th Street Bridge. The 1960s band Simon and Garfunkel made the bridge famous in their song “Feelin’ Groovy,” also called “The 59th Street Bridge Song.”

name: Herbert Von King Park
location: 4 designated areas throughout the park (no amplified sound permitted)
address: Herbert Von King Park, 670 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11216, USA
description: Lying in the heart of Brooklyn’s Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood, Herbert Von King Park is a lively town square with a storied history. Originally called Tompkins Park, Von King is one of the first parks in the history of Brooklyn, with a design submitted by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux.

name: Red Hook Park
location: Bay Street near Columbia Street
address: Red Hook Recreation Center, 155 Bay Street, Brooklyn, NY 11231, USA
description: This neighborhood park is bursting with activities. Groups of friends come out to play handball, basketball, or soccer, and plenty of kids cavort in its popular playground. Whenever it's hot out, people cool down in the Olympic-size pool. Those looking for a workout go for a jog around the running track or take advantage of the onsite recreation center, which offers cardio equipment, weight lifting, and exercise classes.

name: Mill Pond Park
location: Exterior Street & 149th Street (Across from Gateway Mall)
address: Mill Pond Park, Major Deegan Expressway, Bronx, NY 10451, USA
description: The 15-acre park, which opened in October 2009, features 16 Deco Turf tennis courts (Deco Turf is the court surface used at the Olympic Games and the U.S. Open), a picnic and sand play area, a shaded outdoor classroom for kids, an ADA-accessible esplanade suitable for jogging, and views of west Harlem along the Harlem River waterfront.

name: Hunts Point Riverside Park
location: Lafayette Ave. & Edgewater Road
address: Hunts Point Riverside Park, Lafayette Avenue, Bronx, NY 10474, USA
description:
Hunts Point Riverside Park is a gateway to the revitalized Bronx River, a major connector to the Bronx River Greenway, and a home to kayakers, canoers, and paddlers from across the city.

This park, once an illegal dumping ground, has been transformed into a waterfront oasis, with a pier for fishing, and a kayak and canoe launch. Even the spray shower and playground takes the shape of built-in canoes, as kids can safely play in the 'water' on hot days.

name: Pelham Bay Park
location: South Picnic Area - Stadium Avenue, behind the tennis courts
address: Pelham Bay Park, Bronc County Line and Middletown Rd, New York, NY 10464
description: Pelham Bay Park is the largest park in New York City, with a 13-mile coastline, salt marshes, shady forests and sunny meadows, a 19th century historic house, the Hunter Island Marine Zoology and Geology Sanctuary, bridle trails, golf courses, bike paths and the only public beach in the Bronx – Orchard Beach.

name: Picnic Peninsula
location: Pier 5
address: Picnic Peninsula, 334 Furman Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201, USA
description: Pier 5 is dedicated to active recreation and features playing fields capable of configurations for soccer, lacrosse, rugby, flag football and ultimate Frisbee. Shade sails line the northern and southern sides of the pier to provide shade for spectators. Players and spectators can watch the game from the bleachers and benches situated along the sidelines.
